Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Expectation2: Organize and lead religious education classes for children and adults
Situation2: The regular weekly religious education class for the parish's children is scheduled.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my hands wrapped around a mug of tea gone cold. My partner’s eyes were red-rimmed, their voice trembling as they described the impossible choice their boss had given them. They needed me—needed my comfort, my advice, my presence. I reached out, squeezing their hand, but my mind was already racing. In less than an hour, I was supposed to be at the church, leading the children’s religious education class. Parents counted on me, the kids looked forward to our time together, and I knew how much preparation and care went into each lesson. I could see the clock ticking on the wall, each minute pulling me in two directions. My partner’s pain was raw and immediate, but so was my responsibility to the parish. I felt torn, guilt gnawing at me no matter which way I turned. I wanted to be everything for everyone, but tonight, I couldn’t.
